summary: This document is a June 19, 2008 letter from Kirkland & Ellis LLP and a separate letter from the Law Offices of Allen Guthrie McHugh & Thomas, PLLC, both addressed to the Principal/Senior Associate Deputy Attorney General at the DOJ. The letters argue against a federal prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein, citing legal overreach, prosecutorial misconduct, and the existence of a state plea agreement. They claim the federal investigation is driven by Epstein's wealth and connections, not by the merits of the case. This is a legal memorandum from the defense law firm Allen Guthrie McHugh & Thomas, PLLC, addressed to the U.S. Attorney's Office, arguing against the federal prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein. It critiques the Department of Justice's Criminal Division (CEOS) review as incomplete and flawed, asserts that Epstein's conduct was purely local and lacked the hallmarks of federal child exploitation statutes, and claims witness credibility issues and prosecutorial misconduct undermine the case. This document is a legal filing from the law firm Allen Guthrie McHugh & Thomas, PLLC, dated June 19, 2008, addressed to a U.S. Attorney (likely Alexander Acosta). It is a detailed defense memorandum arguing against federal prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein. It challenges the legal sufficiency of the evidence, disputes the applicability of federal statutes (18 U.S.C. §§ 2422(b), 2423, 1591), and alleges prosecutorial misconduct, including falsehoods in search warrant affidavits and inappropriate witness notification. It also references a separate response from Kirkland & Ellis LLP to a May 19, 2008, letter from a First Assistant U.S. Attorney, accusing that office of misrepresentations. This document is a legal filing from Kirkland & Ellis LLP, representing Jeffrey Epstein, detailing alleged prosecutorial misconduct by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida (SDFL) during the negotiation of Epstein's 2007 non-prosecution agreement. It challenges the SDFL's claims about the agreement's terms, including victim compensation, the nature of the charges, and the conduct of prosecutors. This document is a legal filing from Epstein's defense attorneys (Kirkland & Ellis LLP) to the U.S. Department of Justice, alleging serious prosecutorial misconduct by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida (USAO) during the 2007-2008 investigation and plea negotiations. It details accusations of coercion, misrepresentation, conflicts of interest, improper communications, and leaks to the media, arguing these actions taint the case and should preclude federal prosecution. This document is a legal submission from the law firm Kirkland & Ellis LLP to the Office of the Deputy Attorney General, arguing against federal prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein. It contends that Epstein's conduct (soliciting prostitution, sometimes with minors) falls squarely within state jurisdiction and that applying federal statutes (18 U.S.C. §§ 1591, 2422(b), 2423(b)) would require novel, unprecedented, and impermissible expansions of the law. The submission references Supreme Court decisions (Santos, Cuellar) on statutory interpretation and the rule of lenity, and argues the Department's Petite Policy should bar federal prosecution after state action. This document is a legal memorandum from Kirkland & Ellis LLP, likely representing Jeffrey Epstein, arguing against federal prosecution under statutes 18 U.S.C. §§ 2422(b), 1591, and 2423(b). It contends the evidence does not meet the legal elements for these charges, including lack of proof of knowing inducement of minors, interstate nexus for trafficking, or travel for the purpose of illicit sexual conduct. It frames the case as a matter for state, not federal, prosecution. This document is a legal memorandum from Kirkland & Ellis LLP, likely representing Jeffrey Epstein, arguing against federal prosecution. It presents a summary of evidence from civil discovery, claiming Epstein did not target minors, that women lied about their ages, and that his conduct did not meet the elements of federal statutes. It also references a local Florida case (Barry Kutun) to argue disparate treatment.

events.title: Execution of Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, which suspended the federal grand jury investigation and granted immunity to named associates.

events.title: Scheduled Grand Jury Testimony
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney re-initiated the grand jury investigation, issuing a subpoena for testimony and documents, which the defense claims violates the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: CEOS Review Letter
events.description: The DOJ's Child Exploitation and Obscenity Section (CEOS) issued a letter concluding that prosecuting Epstein would not be an 'abuse of discretion,' a review the defense calls limited and incomplete.

events.title: Supreme Court rulings in Santos and Cuellar
events.description: The Supreme Court issued rulings emphasizing that ambiguous criminal statutes should be interpreted in favor of defendants, not prosecutors.

events.title: Trafficking in Persons National Security Presidential Directive
events.description: President George W. Bush issued a directive defining human trafficking, cited to contrast with the Epstein case.

events.title: FAUSA letter to defense
events.description: First Assistant U.S. Attorney Jay Leflcowitz wrote a letter confirming the DOJ's review process and indicating CEOS had previously considered and rejected defense legal challenges.

events.title: FAUSA Letter to Jay Lefkowitz
events.description: A letter from the First Assistant U.S. Attorney to defense attorney Jay Lefkowitz, which the defense claims is fraught with falsehoods and mischaracterizations of the investigation.

events.title: Deadline to Comply with Modified Agreement
events.description: Prosecutors set a deadline for Epstein to comply with terms of the deferred prosecution agreement, as allegedly unilaterally modified, or face termination of the agreement.

events.title: Meeting at USAO Miami
events.description: A meeting where a CEOS attorney allegedly opined he 'would try the case myself,' indicating a pre-existing belief in the prosecution before a later 'independent' review.

events.title: Acosta's Letter Proposing Modification
events.description: U.S. Attorney Acosta sent a letter proposing modifications to the deferred prosecution agreement, which the defense rejected.

events.title: Meeting on Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: A meeting between Epstein's defense and federal prosecutors where the government dismissed defense objections and threatened a 53-page indictment if a non-prosecution agreement was not finalized by September 21, 2007.

events.title: Request for Factual Allegations
events.description: Both Epstein's defense and the state requested factual allegations from the SDFL to create a truthful recitation of a registrable offense for the plea agreement, but the SDFL failed to provide them.

events.title: Timetable Imposed by SDFL
events.description: U.S. Attorney Acosta sent an email setting a timetable for moving forward, which the defense viewed as an attempt to thwart a review process he had previously agreed to.

events.title: State Grand Jury Indictment
events.description: A Florida Grand Jury indicted Jeffrey Epstein on one count of felony solicitation of prostitution following a police investigation.

events.title: Subpoena of Defense Investigator
events.description: Federal prosecutor AUSA subpoenaed the investigator for Epstein's attorney, Roy Black, seeking information on contacts with witnesses and Epstein, allegedly without proper DOJ approval.

events.title: Prosecutor Threatens Broadened Investigation
events.description: A prosecutor sends a target letter to an Epstein employee, threatening to broaden the investigation to include money laundering and operating an unlicensed money-transmitting business to coerce a state settlement.

events.title: Prosecutor Recommends Attorney for Victims
events.description: Prosecutor Sloman recommends attorney Humberto Ocariz to represent the government's list of alleged victims in civil claims against Epstein, later found to have a conflict of interest.

events.title: Prosecutor Demands Accelerated Plea and No Victim Contact
events.description: Prosecutor Sloman demands Epstein's state plea and sentencing be moved up to November 2007 and that Epstein's attorneys cease contacting any alleged victims.

events.title: Leaks to New York Times Reporter
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office, including AUSA Sloman, leaks confidential details of the investigation, legal theories, and plea negotiations to New York Times reporter Landon Thomas.

events.title: Supreme Court Decisions in Santos and Cuellar
events.description: The Supreme Court issued decisions in United States v. Santos and Cuellar v. United States, emphasizing narrow construction of federal criminal statutes and the rule of lenity.

events.title: DOJ Letter on Prostitution Enforcement
events.description: The Justice Department sent a letter to the House Judiciary Committee stating that prostitution-related offenses have historically been prosecuted at the state level and that federal jurisdiction is not necessary.

events.title: DOJ Memorandum on Executive Authority
events.description: The Office of Legal Counsel issued a memorandum on Presidential authority to decline to execute unconstitutional statutes, cited to argue the Executive Branch must not exceed its legal bounds.

events.title: Cut-off Date for Offense Conduct
events.description: The document states that all or virtually all of the offense conduct under federal investigation occurred prior to this date, impacting Florida's statute of limitations.

events.title: Pivotal Allegation Made
events.description: An allegation was made in March 2005, referenced as a pivotal allegation in the case against Epstein.

events.title: Statute of Limitations Cut-off
events.description: The defense argues that any alleged conduct occurring before mid-June 2005 cannot be charged under Florida law due to statute of limitations, and thus cannot be a predicate for a federal charge.

events.title: Barry Kutun Plea Agreement
events.description: Barry Kutun pleaded guilty in a Miami-Dade County courtroom to charges related to having sex with underage prostitutes and videotaping sessions. He received five years probation and no requirement to register as a sex offender, with federal prosecutors declining to prosecute.

events.title: Death of Epstein's Mother
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's mother died in April 2004. The document notes he regularly visited her in south Florida while she was hospitalized and convalescing.

events.title: Epstein's Regular Presence in Palm Beach
events.description: The document states Epstein spent at least 100 days a year in Palm Beach for family, business, and social purposes, with no month from 2003-2005 where he did not spend at least one weekend there.

keyFacts: Epstein's defense attorneys allege the federal investigation is motivated by his wealth and connection to former President Bill Clinton, not the legal merits.
A 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement suspended the federal grand jury and granted immunity to associates, but a new subpoena in 2008 allegedly violates that agreement.
The defense claims key prosecution witnesses have provided exculpatory evidence, denying essential elements needed for a federal case, and accuses the prosecution of withholding Brady material.
The defense alleges specific prosecutorial misconduct, including leaking investigation details to the New York Times and an AUSA attempting to steer business to a friend.

The defense argues the alleged activities (scheduling via phone, in-person encounters in Palm Beach) lack the interstate commerce nexus required for the federal statutes (18 U.S.C. §§ 2422, 2423, 1591) being considered.
The defense argues Epstein's conduct was 'purely local,' lacking interstate travel, commercial enterprise, force, violence, drugs, or child pornography required for federal statutes.
The memo claims the DOJ's Criminal Division (CEOS) review was limited, not de novo, and did not consider allegations of prosecutorial misconduct or fully review witness credibility.

The defense states that state prosecutor Lana Belohlavek conducted a thorough 15-month investigation resulting in a single state felony solicitation charge, which she deemed an appropriate resolution.
The document asserts that evidence shows alleged victims lied to Epstein about being 18, and that he took steps to verify age, undermining the specific intent element for federal charges.
The defense criticizes the FBI agent's search warrant affidavit for containing material misrepresentations and omissions regarding Epstein's intent and the victims' ages.
The defense argues the search warrant affidavit contained 'knowing and reckless falsehoods' regarding the ages and intent elements of the alleged crimes, invoking Franks v. Delaware.
The memorandum contends that to violate key federal statutes (e.g., 18 U.S.C. § 2422(b)), the government must prove Epstein specifically intended to target a known minor, which they claim is absent.
It is claimed that alleged victims repeatedly lied to Epstein about being over 18, and their civil attorney admitted this publicly, supporting an affirmative defense.
The defense accuses the U.S. Attorney's Office of conducting a review that was neither independent nor de novo, as the reviewing attorney had previously endorsed the prosecution.
The document describes an inappropriate witness notification letter that was halted after defense objections; the letter allegedly misstated the law and encouraged civil litigation.

The filing alleges the SDFL created confusion by demanding Epstein plead to a 'registrable' sex offense for which the state had no evidence, while insisting on an offense ('solicitation of minors for prostitution') that required no registration.

It claims the SDFL required Epstein to waive his right to contest civil liability under 18 U.S.C. § 2255 for a list of undisclosed 'victims,' agreeing to pay each at least $150,000, a term described as 'absolutely unprecedented' in a deferred prosecution agreement.
The document states that depositions of women on the government's 'victim' list revealed some testified they were not victims, suffered no injury, and had told Epstein they were adults.
It alleges prosecutorial misconduct, including an AUSA proposing a victim's attorney (Humberto Ocariz) who had a personal connection to her (her boyfriend's former roommate) without disclosing it.

The filing accuses federal prosecutors of using coercive tactics, including threatening Epstein with a draconian 53-page indictment identifying 40 minors if he did not finalize the non-prosecution agreement by a set deadline.
Epstein's defense alleges prosecutors coerced a state settlement by threatening to add baseless financial charges (money laundering, unlicensed money transmission) to the sex offense investigation.

Prosecutors are accused of misrepresenting the number of minor victims, initially claiming '40' minors, then revising to '34 confirmed minor victims' and admitting only one was definitely still under 18.

A prosecutor (Sloman) recommended attorney Humberto Ocariz for lucrative victim representation, while concealing that the recommendation came from her live-in boyfriend, a serious alleged conflict of interest.
The U.S. Attorney's Office allegedly leaked extensive confidential case details, including plea negotiation terms, to New York Times reporter Landon Thomas, violating Department policy.

The filing suggests a prosecutor (Sloman) had an undisclosed former partnership with attorney Jeffrey Herman, who filed multiple civil suits against Epstein, implying an improper motive to encourage litigation.
Epstein's defense argues his conduct was local solicitation of prostitution (being a 'John'), not federal sex trafficking or coercion under §§ 1591, 2422(b), or 2423(b).
The defense claims there is no precedent for applying these federal statutes to a 'John' and that doing so would require a 'novel' and impermissible expansion of federal law.
The submission argues Epstein did not personally use interstate facilities (phone, internet) to communicate with witnesses or knowingly induce minors for sex, a key element of § 2422(b).
It cites the Department's Petite Policy and a 2007 DOJ letter to argue prostitution is traditionally a state matter and federal prosecution after state action is barred.

The defense contends many masseuses lied about their age and visited voluntarily, often with friends or family, and that sexual activity was sporadic and not pre-arranged via interstate communication.
The defense argues there is insufficient evidence that Jeffrey Epstein knowingly induced or persuaded minors over the phone or internet, a key element of 18 U.S.C. § 2422(b).
The memorandum contends that topless massages, even for hire, fall outside Florida's legal definition of 'prostitution,' undermining the predicate for federal charges.

It asserts that Florida's statute of limitations (1 year for misdemeanors, 3 years for felonies) bars prosecution for any alleged conduct before mid-June 2005 under state law, and thus also as a basis for federal charges.

The defense argues Epstein's travel to his home in Palm Beach was not 'for the purpose of' engaging in illicit sexual conduct with a minor, as required by 18 U.S.C. § 2423(b), but simply to return home.

The document claims the case lacks the hallmarks of federal sex trafficking (18 U.S.C. § 1591) cases, such as force, coercion, drugs, or a for-profit enterprise, and should be a matter for state prosecution.
The defense argues Jeffrey Epstein did not target minors, claiming women often lied to him about being 18 or older.
The defense asserts Epstein did not use interstate commerce (telephone, internet) to coerce or entice alleged victims for sexual activity.
The document references the case of Barry Kutun to argue disparate treatment, as Kutun faced only state charges for similar alleged conduct without federal prosecution.
The defense claims all sexual activity was unplanned, consensual, and involved no force, coercion, violence, alcohol, or drugs.
The memorandum concludes by requesting the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida to discontinue its involvement and return the case to the State of Florida.
